content.webTitle: Animals farmed: Pet smuggling, animal testing and swine fever warnings

fields.headline: Animals farmed: Pet smuggling, animal testing and swine fever warnings
fields.bodyText: Almost a quarter of the world’s pigs are expected to die from African Swine Fever (ASF), with Chinese authorities having already warned that the country’s pig population was 40% smaller this year. European food safety officials have said countries in south-east Europe, including Croatia and Greece, were most at risk from ASF spreading through their pig herds. Ecuador has emerged as a major supplier for China’s surging demand for shrimp. Chinese demand has doubled over the past decade, but disease outbreaks in its domestic industry have left it increasingly reliant on imports. China has also now lifted its ban on Canadian beef and pork imports, enacted after residues of the banned feed additive ractopamine were found. A new campaign funded by the European livestock sector has warned the EU risks a rural exodus if it goes forward with any plan to significantly reduce livestock numbers. It follows reports calling for a 40–50% reduction in the size of Europe’s meat and livestock sector to reduce its environmental footprint. Separately, scientists have claimed the €60bn (£51bn) a year common agricultural policy (CAP), which hands out subsidies to farmers, is largely ineffective at retaining or restoring biodiversity. Australian farmers have celebrated rainfall after one of the country’s longest ever dry spells. Persistent drought has become an established problem for farmers now across New South Wales and southern Queensland. One of the world’s largest independent seafood companies has apologised after undercover footage filmed at one of its salmon hatcheries showed disfigured salmon being scooped out of overcrowded tanks and tossed into plastic containers where they are left to slowly suffocate. Cooke, which operates salmon farms in the US, Scotland, and Chile, is now being investigated by state officials in Maine, where the farm was located. The EU is reported to be considering a clampdown on the smuggling on cats, dogs and other pets across its borders. And images emerged from a laboratory near Hamburg of tests on animals, reigniting discussion of this long-running issue. Quote of the month “I’ve always wanted to open a chippy called Woo Tan Scran because the name is hilarious. I never thought it was actually going to happen.” Alex Woo, on opening the first vegan Chinese chippy in Liverpool. (For international readers, “scran” is slang for food.) Joe claimed it makes no sense to shun British meat in favour of a “plant-based diet of avocados or almonds grown in some of the driest places on Earth using blue water sucked from rivers, lakes or aquifers”.
